Hear are examples of simple formating in Markdown.
Note that nothing except the YAML header section (section \@ref(yaml-header)) is specific to R Markdown.

# Headings

We can create a heading with `#`, so for a level one heading we use:

- `# Heading level 1`
- `## Heading level 2`
- `### Heading level 3`

and so on.
If we have numbered sections turned on (as we do in on this page), these heading will be automatically numbered.

# Simple text formating

As demonstrated in the [prior page](../../../../2022/05/10/rational-and-markdown-basics), we can wrap text with `*` to get bold and italic text:

- **bold text** = `**bold text**`
- *italic text* = `*italic text*`
- ***bold and italic text*** = `***bold and italic text***`

To start a new paragraph you need to leave a blank line.

This is a second paragraph
I'd recommend putting sentence on separate lines as I find it easier to read when looking at the source file, and it comes in handy if you use version control.
